articles.headline: Bidders for Tribune Plan Moves
articles.snippet: The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of Tribune has not discouraged potential buyers — and even his rival bidders — from planning their next move.
articles.abstract: The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of Tribune has not discouraged potential buyers — and even his rival bidders — from planning their next move.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news that Samuel Zell is becoming the new chairman of the Tribune Company and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers has not discouraged potential buyers — and even his rival bidders — from planning their next move.
articles.byline: By Richard Siklos and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: India’s Edge Goes Beyond Outsourcing
articles.snippet: The outsourcing of jobs to countries like India has increasingly included the jobs of Western white-collar elites.
articles.abstract: The outsourcing of jobs to countries like India has increasingly included the jobs of Western white-collar elites.
articles.lead_paragraph: Outsourcing is breaking out of the back office.

articles.headline: One Safety Net Is Disappearing. What Will Follow?
articles.snippet: Layoffs at Circuit City last week suggest that experience isn’t as valuable as we would like to think.
articles.abstract: Layoffs at Circuit City last week suggest that experience isn’t as valuable as we would like to think.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, American companies have built a pretty extensive social safety net for their workers. The clearest examples of it are pensions and health insurance, which became popular during the wage freeze of World War II, when employers were looking for creative ways to give raises. Today, the United States is the only major country in the world where the private sector plays such a big role in caring for the old and the sick.

articles.headline: Russia Challenges the U.S. Monopoly on Satellite Navigation
articles.snippet: Russia plans to launch eight navigation satellites to compete with the Global Positioning System operated by the U.S.
articles.abstract: Russia plans to launch eight navigation satellites to compete with the Global Positioning System operated by the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 3 — The days of their cold war may have passed, but Russia and the United States are in the midst of another battle — this one a technological fight over the United States monopoly on satellite navigation.

articles.headline: An Arid West No Longer Waits for Rain
articles.snippet: Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West’s quest for water in decades.
articles.abstract: Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West’s quest for water in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Western drought that began in 1999 has continued after the respite of a couple of wet years that now feel like a cruel tease. But this time people in the driest states are not just scanning the skies and hoping for rescue.
articles.byline: By Randal C. Archibold and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: The Money Binge
articles.snippet: Cheap debt and big investors clamoring for a cut of the action are fueling a record buyout boom.
articles.abstract: Cheap debt and big investors clamoring for a cut of the action are fueling a record buyout boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: LESS than a decade ago, Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman of the Blackstone Group, used to spend his days flying from city to city to drum up money for his private equity funds. “If I could raise $10 million, that was a good day,” he recalled recently.

articles.headline: Vermont Becomes ‘Offshore’ Insurance Haven
articles.snippet: Vermont, which offers U.S. companies lucrative tax breaks, has become the insurance destination of choice.
articles.abstract: Vermont, which offers U.S. companies lucrative tax breaks, has become the insurance destination of choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: At conferences of the offshore insurance industry, next to the booth for Bermuda, can often be found one promoting Vermont.

articles.headline: McCain Revamps His Fund-Raising
articles.snippet: The maneuvers come at a time when the senator is lagging in fund-raising and under fire for his support of the Iraq war.
articles.abstract: The maneuvers come at a time when the senator is lagging in fund-raising and under fire for his support of the Iraq war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 — Lagging in fund-raising and under fire for his support of the Iraq war, Senator John McCain is overhauling his campaign finance operation and delaying the official announcement of his candidacy, his aides said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Will a Hedge Fund Become the Next Goldman Sachs?
articles.snippet: Citadel Investment Group has become one of the most powerful and fastest-growing companies in the hedge fund business, with more than $13.5 billion of capital.
articles.abstract: Citadel Investment Group has become one of the most powerful and fastest-growing companies in the hedge fund business, with more than $13.5 billion of capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 1988, a very young-looking 19-year-old Harvard student sneaked past the receptionist at the Boston office of Merrill Lynch, found the manager in charge of convertible bonds and struck up a conversation about the technical aspects of valuing those bonds.
